_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary: GME Trenton Facility

The Trenton Oil Facility Overview and RMP Regulated Substance

The Grayson Mill Energy Trenton Oil Facility (Facility), is an oil blending Facility that primarily utilizes three product feedstocks:
Crude Oil: Crude oil is brought to the Facility via incoming pipelines and truck-in operations. The crude oil is then stored in the onsite storage tanks. 
Heavy Crude Oil: Heavy crude oil will be trucked into a newly constructed tank farm. 
Butane: The Butane will be trucked to the site and loaded into two (2) 90,000 USG low-pressure (LP) storage bullets.

The Facility was recently expanded to include storage for Heavy Oil and Butane as well as the equipment required to blend the Heavy Oil, Butane, and existing Crude Oil together. A list of major equipment located onsite can be seen below. 
	Two (2) Heavy Oil Storage Tanks
	Two (2) 90,000 USG Low Pressure (LP) Butane Storage Bullets
	One (1) Blending Skid 
	Two (2) Heavy Oil Offloading Stations 
	Two (2) Butane Offloading Stations 
	Two (2) Heavy Oil Blend Pumps 
	Two (2) Butane Blend Pumps 
	Two (2) Crude Oil Booster Pumps
	Two (2) 1000 USG Propane Bullets

A brief overview of the Facility process is as follows. Heavy oil is pumped to the blending skid where it is blended with crude oil. The heavy oil and crude oil blend passes through a static mixer before it is blended with Butane. The Butane blended product will then pass through a second static mixer before being measured by a vapor pressure analyzer. The newly blended product will be directed to the mainline pump for transfer to the Dakota Access Pipeline (DAPL) or Enbridge.

The regulated substance at the Trenton Oil Facility is Butane. The process in which the Butane is utilized is Butane Blending with the crude oil blend prior to being directed to DAPL or Enbridge. The Butane will be stored at the Facility in two (2) 90,000 USG bullets. Butane will be trucked in and loaded into the Butane bullets via two (2) Butan

e Offloading Stations.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
The Trenton Oil Facility has its own site-specific Emergency Response Plan (ERP).   Contained in the ERP are instructions for operators of the Facility to follow should an emergency occur. The Emergency Response Plan contains procedures for the detection, notification, and activation of the site-specific ERP. If required, external agencies can be contacted via the phone numbers provided in the ERP. There are also Defined Situations of Hazards and Accidents (DSHAs) action plans to assist Grayson Mill Energy responders in responding to emergencies at the Facility. The Grayson Mill Energy operations team in North Dakota also conducts Emergency Response Plan drills and exercises, which allow them to practice responding to tangible emergencies should they occur. 

General Accidental Release Prevention Program
The recent addition of the Butane Bullets to the Trenton Oil Facility required updates to the operations instruction manuals as well as the sites maintenance processes. In addition to the updates to existing instruction manuals and maintenance processes, the operations team at the Trenton Oil Facility will also be trained on the new processes required to operate the site. The facilitys site-specific ERP will also be updated to include response procedures should an emergency occur which affects the regulated substance, Butane.

Five Year Accident History
The Trenton Oil Facility has not had any accidental releases of crude oil or other products in the past five years.

Grayson Mill Energy Emergency Response Program
As mentioned previously, the Trenton Oil Facility has a site-specific Emergency Response Plan (ERP). The ERP has been updated to include information and response actions specific to the addition of the Butane Bullets to the Facility site. The ERP also contains actions specific to how the response team (ICS) will be activated as well as how members of the public will ge

t notified should an emergency occur. 

In addition, the Grayson Mill Energy North Dakota team regularly completes emergency response drills to ensure that the local operation teams are ready to respond should an emergency occur at the Trenton Oil Facility. 

Safety Improvements at the Trenton Oil Facility
With the addition of the new processing equipment and storage tanks/vessels at the Trenton Oil Facility, the operations team has provided training to all personnel who would be required to operate the Trenton Oil Facility. The new equipment and storage tanks/vessels will also be installed to the latest standards, such as ASME, ANSI, API and NFPA. 

The Grayson Mill Energy operations team is committed to ensuring the safe operations of the Trenton Oil Facility to protect the public, the employees, and the environment.
